ABOUT THE ST. AUGUSTINE ART ASSOCIATION

Mission
The St. Augustine Art Association is dedicated to promoting artistic excellence through exhibitions, educational programs, and outreach; to fostering a creative and accessible environment for artists of all backgrounds and skill levels; to guiding the advancement of art in partnership with the community; and to preserving our rich artistic heritage.
Art Making History: 100+ Years of Art
St. Augustine, Florida has a rich artistic history, dating back centuries. From its earliest founding, artist Jacques LeMoyne was sent by the French king to document images of the New World. In the early 1800s, John James Audubon trod the wilds of North Florida classifying and painting the abundant wildlife. At the turn of the century, oil tycoon Henry Flagler enticed artists from New England to paint in his opulent Hotel Ponce de Leon studios for the enjoyment of his wealthy patrons.
Est. January 18, 1924
The St. Augustine Art Association emerged as part of local art history in 1924, when Nina Hawkins, the first female editor of The St. Augustine Record, gathered together wintering artists and writers to form The Pen & Brush Club, which soon became “The Galleon Club.”
Miss Hawkins continued over the years to promote this St. Augustine group of artists through the local newspaper. Other charter members included photographer F. Victor Rahner, writers John and Georjina Jex, and painter John Parker. The
Galleon Club
went through several fits and starts over the next few years, until in 1931, Hildegarde Mueller-Uri and J. Dexter Phinney organized the Club with the intent to transform St. Augustine into a major winter art colony. They persuaded the City of St. Augustine to allow them to use the former Waterworks building in Davenport Park as a clubhouse and exhibition gallery.
When the Great Depression gripped the local economy, it was the successful ad campaign “Like Painting in Europe” launched by the artists and local businesses that drew flocks of artists to the Oldest City. The 1930’s and 40’s saw prominent artists moving to St. Augustine from up north like Nunzio Vayana, Edith Oliver, Louis Vogt, Bill Galpin, Tod Lindenmuth and his wife E.B. Warren, Anthony Thieme, Langston Moffett, and William and Lucy L’Engle.
In 1948, the club officially changed its name to the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA). Membership was at an all-time high–over 500 members–and after moving around from one location to another over the years, it was time for the Art Association to build its own space. The land on Marine Street had been purchased by the organization in 1945 from Hildegarde Mueller-Uri’s parents and the building–what is now the main gallery–opened in February 1954.
Through the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s, the STAAA continued to grow and expand exhibits, memberships and programs. It was incorporated as a non-profit and bylaws amended so that the property will always remain devoted to public charities with a preference for the arts. Despite some financial woes, the members and board directors were creative and held fundraisers like the Art-Mart, Beaux Arts Balls, workshops, concerts and performances. In 1998, thanks to funds donated by Joseph & Faith Tiberio, the building was expanded by the addition of the two wing galleries, allowing for more growth and space. In that same year a new source of funding became available, “The St. Augustine Art & Craft Festival.”
Today, St. Augustine is home to many art galleries and artists, ranging from amateurs and students to internationally acclaimed professionals. With its extensive Permanent Collection of important St. Augustine art, large active membership and ever-expanding exhibitions, programs and partnerships, the STAAA thrives and is recognized as the cultural epicenter of the local art community.
On January 18, 1924, a handful of visionaries in St. Augustine, Florida, founded an art group that over time grew into a vibrant and influential force for the arts–the St. Augustine Art Association. This video features historian Susan Parker and two distinguished Art Association members, Tom Rahner and Kay Burtin. Their stories highlight the history of the founding of the St. Augustine Art Association. The project was produced for the Association’s 95th Anniversary in 2019, through a grant from The Community Foundation for Northeast Florida.
This symposium brought to life the people and personalities of St. Augustine’s mid-century art colony. The gathering featured local artists, historians and residents whose research, recollections and first-hand knowledge that shed light on the importance of this regional art movement. A figurative art exhibit with newly acquired and restored portraits complimented the discussion.
Thursday, April 7, 2011
Listen to the Symposium

Exhibit & Event Calendar  (
Events
)
The St. Augustine Art Association is open Tuesdays – Sundays, 12:00 – 4:00 PM.
All year round, the St. Augustine Art Association has plenty of events happening and things to do.
View the full calendar of exhibits, events and activities below — both at the St. Augustine Art Association and at other art galleries in St. Augustine.
Use the following buttons to filter your calendar view between categories.
Exhibits
Events
Calls for Art
Workshops & Classes
Non-Instructional Studio Sessions
AGOSA Events
View
Founders Day St. Augustine Plein Air Paint Out
September 5, 2025
-
September 8, 2025
In celebration of the founding of St. Augustine, the St. Augustine Art Association and the St. Johns Cultural Council are hosting a four-day Plein Air Paint Out. Artists—and art lovers—experience the town's Old-World charm and architectural beauty through the time-honored tradition of painting en plein air (outdoors).
More info
View
Plein Air in the Park
September 14, 2025
In celebration with Art and Bark in the Park, artists are invited to paint en plein air at Lakeside Park!
More info
View
Picturing Paradise: From John James Audubon to the Florida Highwaymen
September 18, 2025
The St. Augustine Lighthouse & Maritime Museum, in partnership with STAAA, invites you to a special evening celebrating art and history in honor of the Lighthouse's 150th Anniversary. Part of the lecture series "History in the Shadow of the Tower," this program highlights the beauty and inspiration of Florida's landscape.
More info
View
Free
First Friday Art Walk
October 3, 2025
Join the St. Augustine Art Association for First Friday Art Walk as we open with the Tactile Art Show and the St. Augustine Camera Club Members Show from 5:00 - 8:00 PM. Awards presented at 7:00 PM.
More info
View
Free
First Friday Art Walk
November 7, 2025
Join the St. Augustine Art Association for First Friday Art Walk as we open with the Fantastic Florida exhibit from 5:00 - 8:00 PM. Awards presented at 7:00 PM.
More info
View
A Celebration of Art & History: The Ximenez-Fatio Nights of Lights Exhibition
November 15, 2025
-
January 5, 2026
For this year's Nights of Lights "Art and History" Exhibition, the Ximenez-Fatio House Museum — in partnership with the St. Augustine Art Association — invites artists to celebrate the Semi-quincentennial (250th) of the American Revolution through a creative fireplace mantel display.
More info
View
Plein Air Nocturne
December 10, 2025
Artists are invited to paint a Nights of Lights nocturne in historic St. Augustine, Florida! Be inspired by the Spanish architecture, coastal environment, small-town streets, and Old-World charm of the nation’s oldest city during the holidays. The works created during this exhibit will be on display at the St. Augustine St. Augustine County Admin Rotunda Gallery exhibit in October 2026.
More info
View
Plein Air Weekend
March 20, 2026
-
March 22, 2026
Artists are invited to paint in this Plein Air weekend event held in historic St. Augustine, Florida! Be inspired by the Spanish architecture, coastal environment, small-town streets, and Old-World charm of the nation's oldest city!
More info
View
10th Annual St. Augustine Plein Air Paint Out
April 24, 2026
-
April 26, 2026
Artists are invited to participate in the annual Plein Air Paint Out in historic St. Augustine, Florida! Be inspired by the Spanish architecture, coastal environment, small-town streets, and Old-World charm of the nation's oldest city!
More info
/.sc_events
Programs & Exhibits of the St. Augustine Art Association are funded in part by  grants from the the St. Johns County Tourist Development Council,
the St. Johns County Cultural Council, and the Community Foundation of Northeast Florida.

Join the St. Augustine Art Association Art Galleries of St. Augustine
The Art Galleries of St. Augustine (AGOSA)
is a diverse collection of art galleries, museums and artists located in St. Augustine, Florida. Each one showcases outstanding local, regional, national & international artists.
To be included in the AGOSA list, galleries can join the St. Augustine Art Association at the annual
Gallery Membership
level!
To qualify for a Gallery Membership, a business must:
Generate 100% of its income from art-related sales and opportunities.
Represent local or regional artists, and offer original artwork for sale.
Be located in St. Augustine or St. Augustine Beach, FL.
Membership Pricing & Benefits
Gallery Membership
$225
Gallery listed in the printed and digital AGOSA map and brochure.
Gallery listed on the AGOSA page of the STAAA website.
First Friday Art Walk promoted through press releases, newsletters, social media, online community calendars, etc.
Promotion of gallery's unique artist opportunities to the full STAAA membership.
Ability to add gallery's upcoming events to the STAAA online calendar.
Promotion of gallery's events through social media and newsletters.
Please Note: Not all of your events or opportunities may get promoted. The STAAA reserves the right to determine which ones it can promote and which avenues it will use to promote. The STAAA will not send press releases on your business’ behalf. Gallery Memberships are not transferable to individual artists in your gallery.
Membership Form
Joining is easy! Simply fill out the form below and submit*. Once your membership is received, we will send you details on event submission and more. Renewal reminders will be in the mail and via email when it’s time to renew again.
To pay via check,
click to download and complete the paper form
and send with payment to the St. Augustine Art Association – 22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL 32084. Make checks payable to the St. Augustine Art Association.
*Transactions through Stripe should show up on your bank statement as ST AUGUSTINE ART ASSOC or StAugArt
If you have trouble submitting, check the following:
the url begins with HTTPS; all information is correctly input and all required fields are filled in; your browser & device are up to date.

STAFF & BOARD
Jennifer Flynt, Executive Director
Originally from Miami, FL, Jennifer graduated from Miami International University of Art & Design with a degree in graphic design and a passion for art and history. After four and a half years of working in communications, she walked into the St. Augustine Art Association in 2016, and never left. Jennifer oversees all facets of the Art Association including the exhibitions, programs and Permanent Collection.

In her spare time, she enjoys little adventures with her dog Loki, kayaking and gardening. Jennifer can also be found frequently eating around the world at Epcot.
Bailey Poole, Program Director
With a background in museum studies and art history, Bailey first became involved with the St. Augustine Art Association as a curatorial intern from Flagler College in 2017. Having the opportunity to spearhead an exhibit centered around locally-renowned artist, Emmett Fritz, solidified her career interests: combining an appreciation for art with a passion for people. Less than a year later, she officially joined the staff and made a new home here at the Art Association. Now, not only does she organize an ongoing rotation of workshops and educational programming, Bailey also coordinates all of the volunteers, manages memberships, and helps oversee the day to day functions of the gallery.
When not at the gallery, Bailey spends her spare time pursuing her own artistic hobbies -- if she’s not chasing after her dog Scooby or binging the latest TV series, of course!
Morgan Zoldak, Gallery Assistant
Raised in St. Johns County, Morgan has always been drawn to the charm of St. Augustine—especially its history and beautiful architecture. She earned her B.A. in Art History and Economics from Florida State University before moving to New York, where she pursued an M.A. in Art Market Studies at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Over the past six years, Morgan has immersed herself in New York City's arts scene, working across various creative spaces such as galleries and art fairs. Last spring, she returned to St. Johns County and had a full-circle moment upon reconnecting with the St. Augustine Art Association—an organization where she once exhibited her ceramics as a high school student. Beyond the gallery, Morgan is a passionate educator who teaches chess to children, a friendly barista who can craft your favorite cup of coffee without fail, and a yoga enthusiast striving to perfect her shoulder stand someday soon!
Catherine Avery St. Jean, President of the Board of Directors
Catherine was born in Iowa, earned her BA in Communications from Loyola University in Chicago and then started a career in Advertising that took her to Madison Avenue. Catherine and her husband relocated to St. Augustine, Florida, arriving on New Year's Day in 2012. She joined the St. Augustine Art Association in 2014 and, by 2015, became actively involved as Chair of Receiving for exhibitions and became a Life Member. In 2017, she helped relaunch the Plein Air Paint Out, transforming it into a celebrated event for artists and art enthusiasts. In 2022, she joined the Board of Directors. Additionally, Catherine dedicated eight years to the St. Johns County Library Advisory Board, where she championed library initiatives to better serve the community. She also is active in The Ancient City Poet Society's Annual Poet Fest each year.

STAFF & BOARD
Jennifer Flynt, Executive Director
Originally from Miami, FL, Jennifer graduated from Miami International University of Art & Design with a degree in graphic design and a passion for art and history. After four and a half years of working in communications, she walked into the St. Augustine Art Association in 2016, and never left. Jennifer oversees all facets of the Art Association including the exhibitions, programs and Permanent Collection.

In her spare time, she enjoys little adventures with her dog Loki, kayaking and gardening. Jennifer can also be found frequently eating around the world at Epcot.
Bailey Poole, Program Director
With a background in museum studies and art history, Bailey first became involved with the St. Augustine Art Association as a curatorial intern from Flagler College in 2017. Having the opportunity to spearhead an exhibit centered around locally-renowned artist, Emmett Fritz, solidified her career interests: combining an appreciation for art with a passion for people. Less than a year later, she officially joined the staff and made a new home here at the Art Association. Now, not only does she organize an ongoing rotation of workshops and educational programming, Bailey also coordinates all of the volunteers, manages memberships, and helps oversee the day to day functions of the gallery.
When not at the gallery, Bailey spends her spare time pursuing her own artistic hobbies -- if she’s not chasing after her dog Scooby or binging the latest TV series, of course!
Morgan Zoldak, Gallery Assistant
Raised in St. Johns County, Morgan has always been drawn to the charm of St. Augustine—especially its history and beautiful architecture. She earned her B.A. in Art History and Economics from Florida State University before moving to New York, where she pursued an M.A. in Art Market Studies at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Over the past six years, Morgan has immersed herself in New York City's arts scene, working across various creative spaces such as galleries and art fairs. Last spring, she returned to St. Johns County and had a full-circle moment upon reconnecting with the St. Augustine Art Association—an organization where she once exhibited her ceramics as a high school student. Beyond the gallery, Morgan is a passionate educator who teaches chess to children, a friendly barista who can craft your favorite cup of coffee without fail, and a yoga enthusiast striving to perfect her shoulder stand someday soon!
Catherine Avery St. Jean, President of the Board of Directors
Catherine was born in Iowa, earned her BA in Communications from Loyola University in Chicago and then started a career in Advertising that took her to Madison Avenue. Catherine and her husband relocated to St. Augustine, Florida, arriving on New Year's Day in 2012. She joined the St. Augustine Art Association in 2014 and, by 2015, became actively involved as Chair of Receiving for exhibitions and became a Life Member. In 2017, she helped relaunch the Plein Air Paint Out, transforming it into a celebrated event for artists and art enthusiasts. In 2022, she joined the Board of Directors. Additionally, Catherine dedicated eight years to the St. Johns County Library Advisory Board, where she championed library initiatives to better serve the community. She also is active in The Ancient City Poet Society's Annual Poet Fest each year.

Mission
The St. Augustine Art Association is dedicated to promoting artistic excellence through exhibitions, educational programs, and outreach; to fostering a creative and accessible environment for artists of all backgrounds and skill levels; to guiding the advancement of art in partnership with the community; and to preserving our rich artistic heritage.
Art Making History: 100+ Years of Art
St. Augustine, Florida has a rich artistic history, dating back centuries. From its earliest founding, artist Jacques LeMoyne was sent by the French king to document images of the New World. In the early 1800s, John James Audubon trod the wilds of North Florida classifying and painting the abundant wildlife. At the turn of the century, oil tycoon Henry Flagler enticed artists from New England to paint in his opulent Hotel Ponce de Leon studios for the enjoyment of his wealthy patrons.
Est. January 18, 1924
The St. Augustine Art Association emerged as part of local art history in 1924, when Nina Hawkins, the first female editor of The St. Augustine Record, gathered together wintering artists and writers to form The Pen & Brush Club, which soon became “The Galleon Club.”
Miss Hawkins continued over the years to promote this St. Augustine group of artists through the local newspaper. Other charter members included photographer F. Victor Rahner, writers John and Georjina Jex, and painter John Parker. The
Galleon Club
went through several fits and starts over the next few years, until in 1931, Hildegarde Mueller-Uri and J. Dexter Phinney organized the Club with the intent to transform St. Augustine into a major winter art colony. They persuaded the City of St. Augustine to allow them to use the former Waterworks building in Davenport Park as a clubhouse and exhibition gallery.
When the Great Depression gripped the local economy, it was the successful ad campaign “Like Painting in Europe” launched by the artists and local businesses that drew flocks of artists to the Oldest City. The 1930’s and 40’s saw prominent artists moving to St. Augustine from up north like Nunzio Vayana, Edith Oliver, Louis Vogt, Bill Galpin, Tod Lindenmuth and his wife E.B. Warren, Anthony Thieme, Langston Moffett, and William and Lucy L’Engle.
In 1948, the club officially changed its name to the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA). Membership was at an all-time high–over 500 members–and after moving around from one location to another over the years, it was time for the Art Association to build its own space. The land on Marine Street had been purchased by the organization in 1945 from Hildegarde Mueller-Uri’s parents and the building–what is now the main gallery–opened in February 1954.
Through the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s, the STAAA continued to grow and expand exhibits, memberships and programs. It was incorporated as a non-profit and bylaws amended so that the property will always remain devoted to public charities with a preference for the arts. Despite some financial woes, the members and board directors were creative and held fundraisers like the Art-Mart, Beaux Arts Balls, workshops, concerts and performances. In 1998, thanks to funds donated by Joseph & Faith Tiberio, the building was expanded by the addition of the two wing galleries, allowing for more growth and space. In that same year a new source of funding became available, “The St. Augustine Art & Craft Festival.”
Today, St. Augustine is home to many art galleries and artists, ranging from amateurs and students to internationally acclaimed professionals. With its extensive Permanent Collection of important St. Augustine art, large active membership and ever-expanding exhibitions, programs and partnerships, the STAAA thrives and is recognized as the cultural epicenter of the local art community.
On January 18, 1924, a handful of visionaries in St. Augustine, Florida, founded an art group that over time grew into a vibrant and influential force for the arts–the St. Augustine Art Association. This video features historian Susan Parker and two distinguished Art Association members, Tom Rahner and Kay Burtin. Their stories highlight the history of the founding of the St. Augustine Art Association. The project was produced for the Association’s 95th Anniversary in 2019, through a grant from The Community Foundation for Northeast Florida.
This symposium brought to life the people and personalities of St. Augustine’s mid-century art colony. The gathering featured local artists, historians and residents whose research, recollections and first-hand knowledge that shed light on the importance of this regional art movement. A figurative art exhibit with newly acquired and restored portraits complimented the discussion.
Thursday, April 7, 2011

Become a Member of the St. Augustine Art Association
Whether you are a seasoned professional, a student, an amateur or hobby artist, an avid art collector, or someone who simply appreciates art, the St. Augustine Art Association has a membership for you. Take a look at the membership levels and benefits below and choose which one suits you best!
Ready to join now? Click the button below to skip to the Membership Form.
Click here to Join
“I want to show my art in a gallery. Where do I begin?” • “What if I get rejected?” • “How do I promote myself?”
At the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA), we are all too familiar with the challenges artists face, and we are here to help and guide you. Whether you’re a seasoned professional, a student, or hobby artist, showing your work can be a daunting process. Becoming a member of the St. Augustine Art Association is your first step to getting your work seen. STAAA member artists can build their résumés, improve their skills, find a niche to establish their work, and build a community and following.
For Artists
Monthly Themed Exhibits featured both in-gallery and online
Two Member Shows a Year with Guaranteed Artwork Acceptance
Juried Exhibits with Cash Awards
Promotion through e-news, social media, some paid advertising, press releases and more that targets audiences from Central FL to South GA.
Art Sales: Low Commissions, Online Art Sales, STAAA arranges shipping when applicable, STAAA collects and pays the FL sales tax, STAAA issues 1099s when applicable
Expanded opportunities to show your art, like the
Plein Air Paint Out
and occasional online-only exhibits promoted on website and other digital medias
For Non-Artists
If you’re a collector, check out our
Exhibit Season Calendar
and decide which shows might have work that you’re most interested in. Exhibits open on the first Friday of every month and
First Friday Art Walk
is from 5-8:00pm!
Follow us on
Facebook
&
Instagram
to stay connected and see some of the works currently on display.
Check out the
volunteer options
we have that might interest you and we’ll get you plugged in. A great way to meet other members is through receiving, installing, or being a daily docent. There are plenty of opportunities to see exhibits early, meet the artists and other art appreciators (Art Walks & Special Events). Let us know your interests, skills and availability and we’ll help you find the right volunteer position!
If you are a supporter of the arts, please contact our Administrator,
Jennifer Flynt
, about sponsor and partnership opportunities.
Membership Levels & Benefits
Individual Membership
$60
For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Discounts on: Show entry fees, art sales commissions, workshops & classes, select items in Gift Shop, Plein Air Paint Out registration; opportunity to show work in
2 Member-only Shows per year;
Invitations to Special Events;
Opportunities to compete for awards
Family Membership
$100
For 2 adults and any children under 18 all in the same household. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Same benefits as Individual Membership + Discount on Art Camps.
Student Membership
$25
For full-time active students in lower or higher education. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Same benefits as Individual Membership.
Patron Membership
$250
For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Benefits same as Individual Membership + Discount on Art Camp, 10% Discount on Art Purchases, VIP access to shows (5-6pm Art Walk preview w/artist meet-n-greet w/refreshments)
Life Membership
$1,000
Benefits same as Individual and Patron but without the need to renew every year.
How to get the most out of your membership
Once you’ve joined you can start taking advantage of the opportunities we offer!
View our
Exhibit Season Calendar
–the next season is announced every late July/early August–and decide which shows you would like to enter. If you don’t think your work fits a certain theme, that’s OK! There are two
Member Shows
–one in the Spring and one in the Fall–with no theme, and no judging, except for awards. Other shows that don’t have strict subject themes are
Miniature Marvels
(if you can work small, size does matter for this one), and if you’re inspired by Florida,
Florida Wild
.
If you’re not an artist but like to collect art, make sure to note which exhibits look the most interesting to you!
Read through the
Exhibit Guidelines
to understand the scheduling and process of our exhibitions and the presentation requirements. If you have any questions, please reach out! (
info@staaa.org)
Enter your work — note the entry and Receiving dates and times — come to
First Friday Art Walk
to meet patrons and artists, and see the award winners–maybe you’re one of them!
Follow us on
Facebook
&
Instagram
to stay connected and keep us in your loop by using the hashtag
#staaacreative
Volunteer
Attend or teach workshops
How do I join?
Joining the STAAA is easy! Simply fill out the form and payment below and submit*. STAAA memberships renew on an annual basis, so the month you joined will be the month you renew next year. We’ll send you a renewal reminder in the mail and via email when it’s time to renew.
Membership forms submitted without payment will not be considered active.
For the member levels listed above, there is no application process. Artists do not need to submit images of their work to become a member. Simply complete and submit the form and payment below.
Those joining at the Student Level must complete the fields labeled “Students”. If under 18, information and approval by a parent or legal guardian is required.
*
If you have trouble submitting the membership form: make sure all required fields are completed properly; make sure the url has
https
in front.
If you prefer to pay by cash or check, please download and complete
this form
, and mail to 22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL 32084. Make checks payable to The St. Augustine Art Association.
*Transactions through Stripe should show up on your bank statement as ST AUGUSTINE ART ASSOC or StAugArt

Become a Member of the St. Augustine Art Association
Whether you are a seasoned professional, a student, an amateur or hobby artist, an avid art collector, or someone who simply appreciates art, the St. Augustine Art Association has a membership for you. Take a look at the membership levels and benefits below and choose which one suits you best!
Ready to join now? Click the button below to skip to the Membership Form.
Click here to Join
“I want to show my art in a gallery. Where do I begin?” • “What if I get rejected?” • “How do I promote myself?”
At the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA), we are all too familiar with the challenges artists face, and we are here to help and guide you. Whether you’re a seasoned professional, a student, or hobby artist, showing your work can be a daunting process. Becoming a member of the St. Augustine Art Association is your first step to getting your work seen. STAAA member artists can build their résumés, improve their skills, find a niche to establish their work, and build a community and following.
For Artists
Monthly Themed Exhibits featured both in-gallery and online
Two Member Shows a Year with Guaranteed Artwork Acceptance
Juried Exhibits with Cash Awards
Promotion through e-news, social media, some paid advertising, press releases and more that targets audiences from Central FL to South GA.
Art Sales: Low Commissions, Online Art Sales, STAAA arranges shipping when applicable, STAAA collects and pays the FL sales tax, STAAA issues 1099s when applicable
Expanded opportunities to show your art, like the
Plein Air Paint Out
and occasional online-only exhibits promoted on website and other digital medias
For Non-Artists
If you’re a collector, check out our
Exhibit Season Calendar
and decide which shows might have work that you’re most interested in. Exhibits open on the first Friday of every month and
First Friday Art Walk
is from 5-8:00pm!
Follow us on
Facebook
&
Instagram
to stay connected and see some of the works currently on display.
Check out the
volunteer options
we have that might interest you and we’ll get you plugged in. A great way to meet other members is through receiving, installing, or being a daily docent. There are plenty of opportunities to see exhibits early, meet the artists and other art appreciators (Art Walks & Special Events). Let us know your interests, skills and availability and we’ll help you find the right volunteer position!
If you are a supporter of the arts, please contact our Administrator,
Jennifer Flynt
, about sponsor and partnership opportunities.

Individual Membership
$60
For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Discounts on: Show entry fees, art sales commissions, workshops & classes, select items in Gift Shop, Plein Air Paint Out registration; opportunity to show work in
2 Member-only Shows per year;
Invitations to Special Events;

$100

For full-time active students in lower or higher education. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Same benefits as Individual Membership.

For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Benefits same as Individual Membership + Discount on Art Camp, 10% Discount on Art Purchases, VIP access to shows (5-6pm Art Walk preview w/artist meet-n-greet w/refreshments)

How do I join?
Joining the STAAA is easy! Simply fill out the form and payment below and submit*. STAAA memberships renew on an annual basis, so the month you joined will be the month you renew next year. We’ll send you a renewal reminder in the mail and via email when it’s time to renew.

Those joining at the Student Level must complete the fields labeled “Students”. If under 18, information and approval by a parent or legal guardian is required.

STAFF & BOARD
Jennifer Flynt, Executive Director
Originally from Miami, FL, Jennifer graduated from Miami International University of Art & Design with a degree in graphic design and a passion for art and history. After four and a half years of working in communications, she walked into the St. Augustine Art Association in 2016, and never left. Jennifer oversees all facets of the Art Association including the exhibitions, programs and Permanent Collection.

In her spare time, she enjoys little adventures with her dog Loki, kayaking and gardening. Jennifer can also be found frequently eating around the world at Epcot.
Bailey Poole, Program Director
With a background in museum studies and art history, Bailey first became involved with the St. Augustine Art Association as a curatorial intern from Flagler College in 2017. Having the opportunity to spearhead an exhibit centered around locally-renowned artist, Emmett Fritz, solidified her career interests: combining an appreciation for art with a passion for people. Less than a year later, she officially joined the staff and made a new home here at the Art Association. Now, not only does she organize an ongoing rotation of workshops and educational programming, Bailey also coordinates all of the volunteers, manages memberships, and helps oversee the day to day functions of the gallery.
When not at the gallery, Bailey spends her spare time pursuing her own artistic hobbies -- if she’s not chasing after her dog Scooby or binging the latest TV series, of course!
Morgan Zoldak, Gallery Assistant
Raised in St. Johns County, Morgan has always been drawn to the charm of St. Augustine—especially its history and beautiful architecture. She earned her B.A. in Art History and Economics from Florida State University before moving to New York, where she pursued an M.A. in Art Market Studies at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Over the past six years, Morgan has immersed herself in New York City's arts scene, working across various creative spaces such as galleries and art fairs. Last spring, she returned to St. Johns County and had a full-circle moment upon reconnecting with the St. Augustine Art Association—an organization where she once exhibited her ceramics as a high school student. Beyond the gallery, Morgan is a passionate educator who teaches chess to children, a friendly barista who can craft your favorite cup of coffee without fail, and a yoga enthusiast striving to perfect her shoulder stand someday soon!
Catherine Avery St. Jean, President of the Board of Directors
Catherine was born in Iowa, earned her BA in Communications from Loyola University in Chicago and then started a career in Advertising that took her to Madison Avenue. Catherine and her husband relocated to St. Augustine, Florida, arriving on New Year's Day in 2012. She joined the St. Augustine Art Association in 2014 and, by 2015, became actively involved as Chair of Receiving for exhibitions and became a Life Member. In 2017, she helped relaunch the Plein Air Paint Out, transforming it into a celebrated event for artists and art enthusiasts. In 2022, she joined the Board of Directors. Additionally, Catherine dedicated eight years to the St. Johns County Library Advisory Board, where she championed library initiatives to better serve the community. She also is active in The Ancient City Poet Society's Annual Poet Fest each year.

Become a Member of the St. Augustine Art Association
Whether you are a seasoned professional, a student, an amateur or hobby artist, an avid art collector, or someone who simply appreciates art, the St. Augustine Art Association has a membership for you. Take a look at the membership levels and benefits below and choose which one suits you best!
Ready to join now? Click the button below to skip to the Membership Form.
Click here to Join
“I want to show my art in a gallery. Where do I begin?” • “What if I get rejected?” • “How do I promote myself?”
At the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA), we are all too familiar with the challenges artists face, and we are here to help and guide you. Whether you’re a seasoned professional, a student, or hobby artist, showing your work can be a daunting process. Becoming a member of the St. Augustine Art Association is your first step to getting your work seen. STAAA member artists can build their résumés, improve their skills, find a niche to establish their work, and build a community and following.
For Artists
Monthly Themed Exhibits featured both in-gallery and online
Two Member Shows a Year with Guaranteed Artwork Acceptance
Juried Exhibits with Cash Awards
Promotion through e-news, social media, some paid advertising, press releases and more that targets audiences from Central FL to South GA.
Art Sales: Low Commissions, Online Art Sales, STAAA arranges shipping when applicable, STAAA collects and pays the FL sales tax, STAAA issues 1099s when applicable
Expanded opportunities to show your art, like the
Plein Air Paint Out
and occasional online-only exhibits promoted on website and other digital medias
For Non-Artists
If you’re a collector, check out our
Exhibit Season Calendar
and decide which shows might have work that you’re most interested in. Exhibits open on the first Friday of every month and
First Friday Art Walk
is from 5-8:00pm!
Follow us on
Facebook
&
Instagram

Membership Levels & Benefits
Individual Membership
$60
For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Discounts on: Show entry fees, art sales commissions, workshops & classes, select items in Gift Shop, Plein Air Paint Out registration; opportunity to show work in
2 Member-only Shows per year;
Invitations to Special Events;
Opportunities to compete for awards
Family Membership
$100
For 2 adults and any children under 18 all in the same household. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Same benefits as Individual Membership + Discount on Art Camps.
Student Membership
$25
For full-time active students in lower or higher education. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Same benefits as Individual Membership.
Patron Membership
$250
For one Adult. Renews annually 12 months from date joined. Benefits same as Individual Membership + Discount on Art Camp, 10% Discount on Art Purchases, VIP access to shows (5-6pm Art Walk preview w/artist meet-n-greet w/refreshments)
Life Membership
$1,000
Benefits same as Individual and Patron but without the need to renew every year.
How to get the most out of your membership
Once you’ve joined you can start taking advantage of the opportunities we offer!
View our
Exhibit Season Calendar
–the next season is announced every late July/early August–and decide which shows you would like to enter. If you don’t think your work fits a certain theme, that’s OK! There are two
Member Shows
–one in the Spring and one in the Fall–with no theme, and no judging, except for awards. Other shows that don’t have strict subject themes are
Miniature Marvels
(if you can work small, size does matter for this one), and if you’re inspired by Florida,
Florida Wild
.
If you’re not an artist but like to collect art, make sure to note which exhibits look the most interesting to you!

Exhibit Guidelines
to understand the scheduling and process of our exhibitions and the presentation requirements. If you have any questions, please reach out! (
info@staaa.org)

to meet patrons and artists, and see the award winners–maybe you’re one of them!

How do I join?
Joining the STAAA is easy! Simply fill out the form and payment below and submit*. STAAA memberships renew on an annual basis, so the month you joined will be the month you renew next year. We’ll send you a renewal reminder in the mail and via email when it’s time to renew.
Membership forms submitted without payment will not be considered active.
For the member levels listed above, there is no application process. Artists do not need to submit images of their work to become a member. Simply complete and submit the form and payment below.
Those joining at the Student Level must complete the fields labeled “Students”. If under 18, information and approval by a parent or legal guardian is required.
*
If you have trouble submitting the membership form: make sure all required fields are completed properly; make sure the url has
https
in front.
If you prefer to pay by cash or check, please download and complete
this form
, and mail to 22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL 32084. Make checks payable to The St. Augustine Art Association.
*Transactions through Stripe should show up on your bank statement as ST AUGUSTINE ART ASSOC or StAugArt

Become a Member of the St. Augustine Art Association
Whether you are a seasoned professional, a student, an amateur or hobby artist, an avid art collector, or someone who simply appreciates art, the St. Augustine Art Association has a membership for you. Take a look at the membership levels and benefits below and choose which one suits you best!
Ready to join now? Click the button below to skip to the Membership Form.
Click here to Join
“I want to show my art in a gallery. Where do I begin?” • “What if I get rejected?” • “How do I promote myself?”
At the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA), we are all too familiar with the challenges artists face, and we are here to help and guide you. Whether you’re a seasoned professional, a student, or hobby artist, showing your work can be a daunting process. Becoming a member of the St. Augustine Art Association is your first step to getting your work seen. STAAA member artists can build their résumés, improve their skills, find a niche to establish their work, and build a community and following.
For Artists
Monthly Themed Exhibits featured both in-gallery and online
Two Member Shows a Year with Guaranteed Artwork Acceptance
Juried Exhibits with Cash Awards
Promotion through e-news, social media, some paid advertising, press releases and more that targets audiences from Central FL to South GA.
Art Sales: Low Commissions, Online Art Sales, STAAA arranges shipping when applicable, STAAA collects and pays the FL sales tax, STAAA issues 1099s when applicable
Expanded opportunities to show your art, like the
Plein Air Paint Out
and occasional online-only exhibits promoted on website and other digital medias
For Non-Artists
If you’re a collector, check out our
Exhibit Season Calendar
and decide which shows might have work that you’re most interested in. Exhibits open on the first Friday of every month and
First Friday Art Walk
is from 5-8:00pm!
Follow us on
Facebook
&
Instagram
to stay connected and see some of the works currently on display.
Check out the
volunteer options
we have that might interest you and we’ll get you plugged in. A great way to meet other members is through receiving, installing, or being a daily docent. There are plenty of opportunities to see exhibits early, meet the artists and other art appreciators (Art Walks & Special Events). Let us know your interests, skills and availability and we’ll help you find the right volunteer position!
If you are a supporter of the arts, please contact our Administrator,
Jennifer Flynt
, about sponsor and partnership opportunities.

Exhibit Judge: Patrick Miko
Patrick Miko is a multimedia artist and currently a professor at Florida State College at Jacksonville.
Judge’s Statement
Being an artist is enduring criticism, learning to see things differently, and acknowledging one’s creative imagination while striving to solve problems. No matter the outcome, we continue to develop our aesthetic vision and craftsmanship professionally. Being an art educator, I have honed my skills as a practicing artist and designer, impartially fostering craft and creativity.
Upon entering the St. Augustine Association, I was energized by the plethora of art outcomes and impressed with the variety of mediums, craftsmanship, and aesthetics. This was a tough judication and I wanted to be inclusive to what was submitted. Consequentially, the awards were decisively chosen with regards to craftsmanship, presentation, and creativity; with the notion in mind, that the diversity needs to be recognized.
It has been an honor to reward pieces that showed the ability of an artist to solve a visual art problem representing their dedication, craft, skillset, and imagination. Careful observation and practice are necessary in the evolution of an accomplished artist. Congratulations, St. Augustine Association Members, your works are profound, vast and demonstrate the creative possibilities of learning to see.

Exhibit Judge: Patrick Miko
Patrick Miko is a multimedia artist and currently a professor at Florida State College at Jacksonville.
Judge’s Statement
Being an artist is enduring criticism, learning to see things differently, and acknowledging one’s creative imagination while striving to solve problems. No matter the outcome, we continue to develop our aesthetic vision and craftsmanship professionally. Being an art educator, I have honed my skills as a practicing artist and designer, impartially fostering craft and creativity.
Upon entering the St. Augustine Association, I was energized by the plethora of art outcomes and impressed with the variety of mediums, craftsmanship, and aesthetics. This was a tough judication and I wanted to be inclusive to what was submitted. Consequentially, the awards were decisively chosen with regards to craftsmanship, presentation, and creativity; with the notion in mind, that the diversity needs to be recognized.
It has been an honor to reward pieces that showed the ability of an artist to solve a visual art problem representing their dedication, craft, skillset, and imagination. Careful observation and practice are necessary in the evolution of an accomplished artist. Congratulations, St. Augustine Association Members, your works are profound, vast and demonstrate the creative possibilities of learning to see.

Mission
The St. Augustine Art Association is dedicated to promoting artistic excellence through exhibitions, educational programs, and outreach; to fostering a creative and accessible environment for artists of all backgrounds and skill levels; to guiding the advancement of art in partnership with the community; and to preserving our rich artistic heritage.
Art Making History: 100+ Years of Art
St. Augustine, Florida has a rich artistic history, dating back centuries. From its earliest founding, artist Jacques LeMoyne was sent by the French king to document images of the New World. In the early 1800s, John James Audubon trod the wilds of North Florida classifying and painting the abundant wildlife. At the turn of the century, oil tycoon Henry Flagler enticed artists from New England to paint in his opulent Hotel Ponce de Leon studios for the enjoyment of his wealthy patrons.
Est. January 18, 1924
The St. Augustine Art Association emerged as part of local art history in 1924, when Nina Hawkins, the first female editor of The St. Augustine Record, gathered together wintering artists and writers to form The Pen & Brush Club, which soon became “The Galleon Club.”
Miss Hawkins continued over the years to promote this St. Augustine group of artists through the local newspaper. Other charter members included photographer F. Victor Rahner, writers John and Georjina Jex, and painter John Parker. The
Galleon Club
went through several fits and starts over the next few years, until in 1931, Hildegarde Mueller-Uri and J. Dexter Phinney organized the Club with the intent to transform St. Augustine into a major winter art colony. They persuaded the City of St. Augustine to allow them to use the former Waterworks building in Davenport Park as a clubhouse and exhibition gallery.
When the Great Depression gripped the local economy, it was the successful ad campaign “Like Painting in Europe” launched by the artists and local businesses that drew flocks of artists to the Oldest City. The 1930’s and 40’s saw prominent artists moving to St. Augustine from up north like Nunzio Vayana, Edith Oliver, Louis Vogt, Bill Galpin, Tod Lindenmuth and his wife E.B. Warren, Anthony Thieme, Langston Moffett, and William and Lucy L’Engle.
In 1948, the club officially changed its name to the St. Augustine Art Association (STAAA). Membership was at an all-time high–over 500 members–and after moving around from one location to another over the years, it was time for the Art Association to build its own space. The land on Marine Street had been purchased by the organization in 1945 from Hildegarde Mueller-Uri’s parents and the building–what is now the main gallery–opened in February 1954.
Through the 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s, the STAAA continued to grow and expand exhibits, memberships and programs. It was incorporated as a non-profit and bylaws amended so that the property will always remain devoted to public charities with a preference for the arts. Despite some financial woes, the members and board directors were creative and held fundraisers like the Art-Mart, Beaux Arts Balls, workshops, concerts and performances. In 1998, thanks to funds donated by Joseph & Faith Tiberio, the building was expanded by the addition of the two wing galleries, allowing for more growth and space. In that same year a new source of funding became available, “The St. Augustine Art & Craft Festival.”
Today, St. Augustine is home to many art galleries and artists, ranging from amateurs and students to internationally acclaimed professionals. With its extensive Permanent Collection of important St. Augustine art, large active membership and ever-expanding exhibitions, programs and partnerships, the STAAA thrives and is recognized as the cultural epicenter of the local art community.
On January 18, 1924, a handful of visionaries in St. Augustine, Florida, founded an art group that over time grew into a vibrant and influential force for the arts–the St. Augustine Art Association. This video features historian Susan Parker and two distinguished Art Association members, Tom Rahner and Kay Burtin. Their stories highlight the history of the founding of the St. Augustine Art Association. The project was produced for the Association’s 95th Anniversary in 2019, through a grant from The Community Foundation for Northeast Florida.
This symposium brought to life the people and personalities of St. Augustine’s mid-century art colony. The gathering featured local artists, historians and residents whose research, recollections and first-hand knowledge that shed light on the importance of this regional art movement. A figurative art exhibit with newly acquired and restored portraits complimented the discussion.
Thursday, April 7, 2011
Listen to the Symposium

Featured Artist: John Darovitz
Art Collective
51 Cordova St, St. Augustine, FL, United States
Art Collective St. Augustine is excited to feature artist John Darovitz and his exhibition, "Capturing the Coastal Life" throughout July. John’s artwork is truly unique, created using just four colors and map pins to produce the illusion of depth, dimension, and additional hues. Inspired by the peace, serenity, and sense of oneness that come with coastal living, his stunning body of work invites you to experience the coast in an entirely new way.

Featured Artist: Cynthia Pierson
Butterfield Garage Art Gallery
137 King Street, St. Augustine
Butterfield Garage is thrilled to announce Cynthia Pierson as July’s featured artist! Cynthia is a local pastel artist who captures everything from landscapes and portraits to still lifes and everyday moments. Her work highlights the beauty in everyday life, encouraging viewers to see and appreciate it in their own lives.

Summer Art Camp: Patterns, Papers & Pop-Ups
St. Augustine Art Association
22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL, United States
Recommended for Grades 6 - 9. Let loose and have fun as we mix it up with paper, paint and creative collage to build pop-up art that's as fun to make as it is to show off! From creating books that come to life with every turn of the page to layered cards that pop, fold and twist -- you'll unlock the magic of mixed media collage and innovative design!

Summer Art Camp: Illuminated Imagination
St. Augustine Art Association
22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL, United States
Recommended for Grades 1 - 6. Let's look at artwork through a new lens -- using light, shadows and perspective to make your creations stand out in surprising ways. From glow-in-the-dark paintings to brightly-lit drawings and creations, you'll explore how perspective can change everything. By the end of this week, your works of art will bring an explosion of light to any dark space!

Séance Sketches
St. Augustine Art Association
22 Marine Street, St. Augustine, FL, United States
This Halloween season, step into the shadows and explore the mysterious art of automatic drawing! In this candlelit workshop, you'll experiment with blind and semi-blind mark-making techniques inspired by spiritualists and surrealists -- methods once used to access the subconscious and communicate with the unseen.
